questions.text: If a question doesn't name a specific religion, you can still use examples from your studied tradition to illustrate points.
questions.explanation: General questions must be answered from the perspective of religion generally. Responses completely from a specific tradition receive no marks. Even mixing general and specific points only earns marks for the general content.
questions.studyTip: No tradition named = answer about religion generally. Zero exceptions.

questions.text: Questions about religion generally require you to avoid naming specific traditions or denominations.
questions.explanation: General questions test your understanding of how religion works as a phenomenon, not how your studied tradition works specifically. Keep your answer applicable to all religions.
questions.studyTip: Say 'religions' and 'adherents', not 'Catholics' or 'Muslims'.

questions.text: Extended responses benefit from a comprehensive introduction covering all relevant background.
questions.explanation: Students often lose marks by not answering directly. Superfluous storytelling and excessive background waste time and space. Get to the point the question asks about.
questions.studyTip: First sentence should address the question. No lengthy preambles.

questions.text: High-scoring responses address the question's specific focus from the first paragraph.
questions.explanation: Direct answers demonstrate you understand what's being asked. Every sentence should contribute to answering the question, not just showing what you know.
questions.studyTip: Read the question. Answer that question. Only that question.

questions.text: Using additional pages shows thorough knowledge and commitment.
questions.explanation: Most students who kept responses within provided space scored well. The space guides appropriate length. Overlong responses often include irrelevant material rather than focused analysis.
questions.studyTip: Space provided = length expected. Edit ruthlessly.

questions.text: The allocated space and marks guide appropriate response length.
questions.explanation: Use mark allocation to judge detail needed. A 4-mark question needs more depth than a 2-mark question, but neither needs an essay. Be guided by the exam structure.
questions.studyTip: 3 marks ≈ 3 key points with brief explanation.

questions.text: Content quality matters more than handwriting neatness.
questions.explanation: Illegible handwriting means assessors cannot award marks for your ideas. Many responses were weakened by handwriting that became difficult to read under time pressure.
questions.studyTip: Slow down if your writing is deteriorating. Clarity beats speed.

questions.text: Clear handwriting throughout the exam is essential for earning marks.
questions.explanation: Assessors can only mark what they can read. Practice writing quickly but legibly. If time pressure affects your writing, prioritise key points over volume.
questions.studyTip: Illegible = zero marks, no matter how brilliant.

questions.text: Including detailed quotes and statistics always strengthens your response.
questions.explanation: Sources must be relevant to the question. Memorised quotes that don't address what's asked are considered irrelevant and won't earn marks. Consider why you're including each piece of evidence.
questions.studyTip: Ask: Does this quote answer THIS question? If not, leave it out.

questions.text: Every source and statistic must directly support your answer to the specific question.
questions.explanation: Don't expect marks simply for providing memorised quotes. Material that doesn't expand on the question is irrelevant. Quality and relevance beat quantity.
questions.studyTip: Relevant evidence > impressive-sounding evidence.

questions.text: If a question asks about 'religion' without naming a tradition, you should use your studied tradition as the example.
questions.explanation: Questions about religion generally must be answered generally. Using your specific tradition, even as an example, loses marks. The question tests different knowledge.
questions.studyTip: No tradition named = stay general throughout.

questions.text: General questions test understanding of how religion works as a phenomenon across all traditions.
questions.explanation: These questions assess whether you understand universal features of religion—aspects, purposes, functions—not your knowledge of one particular tradition.
questions.studyTip: Think: What's true of ALL religions? Answer that.

questions.text: Tradition-specific questions can be answered using general points about religion if they're accurate.
questions.explanation: Tradition-specific questions require you to name your tradition accurately and provide theologically correct details about that tradition's specific beliefs and practices.
questions.studyTip: Tradition asked for = specific beliefs, specific practices, specific sources.

questions.text: Tradition-specific questions require accurate naming of the tradition and theologically correct details.
questions.explanation: You must clearly state your tradition and provide precise, accurate information about its beliefs. Vague or theologically incorrect responses score poorly.
questions.studyTip: Name your tradition first. Then be precise and accurate.

concepts.title: Avoid mixing general and specific inappropriately

questions.text: Mixing general points with tradition-specific examples in a general question shows comprehensive knowledge.
questions.explanation: In general questions, tradition-specific points receive no marks. Only the general points (if accurate) earn marks. Keep general questions entirely general.
questions.studyTip: General question + specific example = wasted words.

questions.text: Responses mixing general and specific points only receive marks for content appropriate to the question type.
questions.explanation: If you accidentally include specific examples in a general question, only your general points score. This means you've wasted time and space on unmarked content.
questions.studyTip: Check each sentence: Does it match the question type?

questions.text: Referring to broad concepts like 'salvation' or 'creation' counts as stating a belief.
questions.explanation: Vague references to categories of beliefs don't earn full marks. You must state the actual belief precisely: not 'belief in creation' but 'the belief that God is the creator of the world and everything in it.'
questions.studyTip: 'Belief in X' is a category. 'The belief that...' is a belief.

questions.text: Precise beliefs include specific theological claims, such as 'the belief that God is the divine lawgiver.'
questions.explanation: Strong responses articulate beliefs as complete theological statements. 'The belief in the Trinity, one God in three persons' is precise. 'The belief in God' is not.
questions.studyTip: State it fully: 'The belief that [specific theological claim]...'

questions.text: As long as your belief relates to your tradition, the exact wording doesn't matter much.
questions.explanation: Theological accuracy is essential. Inaccurate descriptions of beliefs—even small errors—indicate misunderstanding and lose marks. Know your tradition's theology precisely.
questions.studyTip: Get the theology right. Close enough isn't good enough.

questions.text: Beliefs must be theologically correct according to your named tradition's official teachings.
questions.explanation: Your stated beliefs should match what your tradition actually teaches. If you're unsure, stick to core doctrines you know accurately rather than attempting complex theology.
questions.studyTip: Unsure? Use a simpler belief you know is correct.

questions.text: 'Stewardship' and 'brotherhood' are beliefs that can be stated in responses.
questions.explanation: These are categories or themes, not beliefs. A belief would be: 'the belief that humans are called to be stewards of God's creation' or 'the belief that all humans are brothers and sisters as children of God.'
questions.studyTip: Category: one word. Belief: complete statement with 'that'.

questions.text: Beliefs must be expressed as complete theological statements, not single-word concepts.
questions.explanation: Transform categories into beliefs: 'suffering' becomes 'the belief that suffering has redemptive purpose when united with Christ's suffering.' Always explain what the tradition believes about the concept.
questions.studyTip: 'The belief that...' forces you to articulate the actual belief.

concepts.title: Link beliefs to the question focus

questions.text: Any accurate belief from your tradition will earn marks regardless of the question.
questions.explanation: Your stated belief must be relevant to what the question asks. A belief about salvation won't help if the question asks about nature and purpose of human life.
questions.studyTip: Right belief, wrong question = no marks.

questions.text: Selected beliefs must directly relate to the specific focus of the question.
questions.explanation: Read what the question asks about—nature of human life, ethics, ultimate reality—then choose beliefs that address that specific area. Relevance is essential.
questions.studyTip: Question about X → belief about X. No substitutions.

questions.text: Defining 'sacred stories' or 'social structures' is enough to answer questions about them.
questions.explanation: Definitions alone don't earn marks unless they explain the function—what the aspect does in religion. You must show how the aspect contributes to the search for meaning, not just what it is.
questions.studyTip: Definition = what it is. Function = what it does. You need both.

questions.text: Questions about aspects require explaining their role or function in religion, not just defining them.
questions.explanation: The question asks how aspects help with the search for meaning. Your answer must connect the aspect's features to how they help adherents find meaning and purpose.
questions.studyTip: Always answer: 'This helps the search for meaning because...'

concepts.title: Connect aspects to search for meaning

questions.text: Claiming that aspects 'answer existential questions' is sufficient explanation.
questions.explanation: This claim is often tagged on without logical connection. You must explain how—specifically—the aspect helps answer those questions. The mechanism matters, not just the claim.
questions.studyTip: 'Answers existential questions' needs a HOW. Explain the mechanism.

questions.text: You must explain the specific way each aspect contributes to adherents' search for meaning.
questions.explanation: Show the connection: sacred stories provide role models for meaningful living; social structures offer guidance through knowledgeable leaders; rituals create spiritual experiences that confirm beliefs.
questions.studyTip: Aspect → specific function → how that helps meaning. Complete the chain.

questions.text: 'Texts' in Religion and Society refers primarily to sacred scriptures.
questions.explanation: The aspect 'texts' includes all forms of communication used by religions: written forms, visual materials, music, art. Responses implying only sacred texts, or naming specific texts, don't earn full marks.
questions.studyTip: 'Texts' = written, visual, musical, artistic. Not just scripture.

questions.text: The aspect 'texts' encompasses various forms of religious communication including written, visual, and musical.
questions.explanation: Think broadly: hymns, icons, theological commentaries, devotional literature, religious art. All are 'texts' that express and communicate religious meaning.
questions.studyTip: Include different text types when discussing this aspect.

concepts.title: Use aspects to discuss expressed beliefs

questions.text: Beliefs can be discussed without reference to how they're expressed through aspects.
questions.explanation: Beliefs are experienced through aspects of religion—texts, rituals, social structures. When asked how beliefs are expressed or how expressions change, you must engage with the aspects directly and by name.
questions.studyTip: Beliefs are expressed THROUGH aspects. Name the aspects.

questions.text: When discussing how beliefs are expressed, you must name the specific aspects of religion involved.
questions.explanation: The phenomenological experience of religion means beliefs become real through aspects. Say: 'This belief is expressed through the ritual of...' or 'The social structure of... communicates this belief.'
questions.studyTip: Express beliefs through: texts, rituals, ethics, social structures, sacred stories.

questions.text: Rewording the same point in different ways counts as making multiple points.
questions.explanation: Many students make one point, then reword it. This doesn't earn additional marks. Two points means two genuinely different ways the aspect functions, not the same idea twice.
questions.studyTip: Two points = two different ideas. Rewording isn't a second point.

questions.text: Questions requiring multiple points need genuinely distinct explanations, not reworded versions of one idea.
questions.explanation: Plan different angles: social structures include leaders (guidance function) AND educational institutions (growth function). Each is a separate point about how the aspect works.
questions.studyTip: Before writing point two, ask: Is this actually different?

questions.text: Putting quotation marks around single words from the question shows you're using sources.
questions.explanation: Quotation marks around single words or restated question phrases don't count as source use. A source is an actual quote from scripture, a scholar, or official teaching—properly cited.
questions.studyTip: A source = actual quote + proper citation. Not keywords in quotes.

questions.text: Sources must be actual quotations with correct citations, not just words in quotation marks.
questions.explanation: Prepare 3–4 quotations per Area of Study. Memorise them with their correct citations: scripture needs text, chapter, verse; scholars need author, title, page.
questions.studyTip: Memorise real quotes WITH their citations. Practice writing them.

questions.text: Naming the general source (e.g., 'the Bible' or 'the Quran') is sufficient citation.
questions.explanation: Primary sources need text, chapter, and verse (e.g., 'Genesis 1:26'). Secondary sources need author, title, and page number. General references aren't proper citations.
questions.studyTip: Scripture: Book Chapter:Verse. Scholar: Name, Title, page.

questions.text: Correct citation includes specific chapter and verse for scripture, or author, title and page for scholars.
questions.explanation: Practice the format: 'as stated in Matthew 22:39' or 'according to [Scholar Name], [Title], p. XX'. Correct citation shows academic rigour.
questions.studyTip: Learn citation format now. It's easy marks.

questions.text: Repeatedly using sacred scripture is adequate source use for challenge questions.
questions.explanation: Analysis of challenges requires referencing a range of historical texts with different interpretations. One source—even scripture—isn't enough. Show you've researched multiple perspectives.
questions.studyTip: Challenges need multiple sources: scripture, councils, scholars, leaders.

questions.text: Challenge analysis requires diverse sources showing different interpretations of the challenge.
questions.explanation: Demonstrate research depth: church councils, papal encyclicals, scholarly analyses, historical documents. Different sources often offer different interpretations of the same challenge.
questions.studyTip: Prepare at least 3 different source types for your challenge.

questions.text: Including well-memorised quotes demonstrates strong preparation, even if tangentially related.
questions.explanation: Irrelevant sources—however impressive—don't earn marks. Every quote must directly support a point that answers the question. Consider why you're including each source.
questions.studyTip: Before including a quote, ask: Does this help answer THIS question?

questions.text: Every source must directly support your answer to the specific question asked.
questions.explanation: Sources should be chosen for relevance, not impressiveness. A simple, relevant quote earns more than an elaborate, tangential one.
questions.studyTip: Relevant and simple beats irrelevant and impressive.

questions.text: A challenge about moral issues is a theological challenge if it affects religious beliefs.
questions.explanation: Many students wrongly classify ethical challenges as theological, or confuse continued existence challenges with theological ones. Theological challenges specifically concern beliefs about God, divinity, or core doctrine.
questions.studyTip: Theological = about God/doctrine. Ethical = about right/wrong. Different types.

questions.text: Theological, ethical, and continued existence challenges are distinct categories requiring different treatment.
questions.explanation: Know your challenge's type: theological (doctrine about God), ethical (moral behaviour), continued existence (survival of tradition). Don't claim a challenge is theological if it's really ethical.
questions.studyTip: Identify your challenge type correctly before the exam.

questions.text: Naming a challenge like 'Darwin's theory' is enough; detailed explanation is optional.
questions.explanation: You must explain precisely what the challenge is and why it's challenging. What exactly did Darwin propose? How specifically does it conflict with religious beliefs about creation?
questions.studyTip: Explain: What is it? Why is it a challenge? Be specific.

questions.text: You must precisely explain what the challenge proposes and why it conflicts with religious beliefs.
questions.explanation: For Arian heresy, explain Arius's teaching and why it was heretical. For Darwin, explain natural selection and its apparent incompatibility with creation beliefs. Precision matters.
questions.studyTip: Prepare a clear, precise explanation of your challenge. Practice it.

concepts.title: Focus on the tradition, not individuals

questions.text: Discussing how key individuals responded to a challenge shows good knowledge of the topic.
questions.explanation: The focus of Unit 4 challenge questions is the religious tradition or denomination, not individuals. Stances, responses, and consequences should be discussed from the tradition's perspective.
questions.studyTip: Challenge questions: tradition focus, not individual focus.

questions.text: Challenge analysis must focus on how the religious tradition responded, not just key individuals.
questions.explanation: Discuss the tradition's official stance, the tradition's supporting responses, the consequences for the tradition. Individuals feature only as they represent or enact the tradition's position.
questions.studyTip: Say 'The Catholic Church...' not 'Pope X...' as your main focus.

questions.text: Stances and supporting responses are essentially the same thing, just different terms.
questions.explanation: Many students confuse these. A stance is the position taken (for, against, or accommodation). Supporting responses are the actions, documents, and decisions that enact or defend that stance.
questions.studyTip: Stance = the position. Response = how they enacted/defended it.

questions.text: Stances are positions taken; supporting responses are actions, documents, and decisions that enact them.
questions.explanation: Keep them separate in your answer. First explain the stance (e.g., opposition to the heresy), then explain supporting responses (e.g., council decisions, excommunications, doctrinal statements).
questions.studyTip: Answer stances in one section, responses in another. Don't mix.

questions.text: Focusing on the religious content is more important than historical context for challenge questions.
questions.explanation: Detailed challenges (Area of Study 2) require relevant wider context. Some responses showed insufficient research and lacked the historical background needed for proper analysis.
questions.studyTip: Know the when, where, and wider situation of your challenge.

questions.text: Challenge analysis requires relevant historical context alongside theological content.
questions.explanation: Place your challenge in context: What was happening in society? What other factors influenced the response? Historical understanding enriches your analysis.
questions.studyTip: Context strengthens analysis. Research the historical setting.

questions.text: Covering the entire history of a challenge shows comprehensive knowledge.
questions.explanation: Challenges spanning long periods lead to unsupported overgeneralisations. Select content from your broad study that fits the question's timeframe—historical or contemporary period.
questions.studyTip: Broad timeframe = vague generalisations. Focus your period.

questions.text: Focusing on a specific timeframe produces more precise, supported analysis than covering entire histories.
questions.explanation: If discussing a historical challenge, limit to the key period. If contemporary, focus on recent decades. Depth in a focused period beats shallow coverage of centuries.
questions.studyTip: Pick your period. Go deep, not wide.

questions.text: You can discuss how your tradition responded to any historical challenge, regardless of timing.
questions.explanation: Your specific tradition or denomination cannot be discussed as responding to challenges that occurred before it existed. A 16th-century denomination didn't respond to a 4th-century challenge.
questions.studyTip: Check: Did your tradition exist when the challenge occurred?

questions.text: Your tradition must have existed at the time of the challenge you're discussing.
questions.explanation: If discussing a historical challenge, ensure your tradition existed then. You might need to discuss the broader tradition (e.g., Christianity) rather than your specific denomination.
questions.studyTip: Historical accuracy: tradition must exist before it can respond.

questions.text: Detailed biographical information about your case study demonstrates thorough preparation.
questions.explanation: Many responses focused on excessive biographical detail without identifying the person's precise religious beliefs. The question asks about how beliefs were affected, not life story.
questions.studyTip: Biography is context. Beliefs are the answer. Keep biography brief.

questions.text: Case study responses must focus on specific religious beliefs, not detailed life narratives.
questions.explanation: State the what, when, and where briefly, then focus on the person's particular beliefs and how faith in those beliefs was affected. That's what earns marks.
questions.studyTip: One paragraph biography max. Rest = beliefs and how they changed.

concepts.title: Identify precise beliefs of your person

questions.text: General references to your person's faith tradition count as identifying their beliefs.
questions.explanation: You must identify the particular beliefs of the person—not just their tradition. What did Oscar Romero specifically believe about justice? What did Elie Wiesel believe about God's presence?
questions.studyTip: Not 'they were Catholic' but 'they believed that...'

questions.text: You must state the specific beliefs held by your case study person, not just their tradition.
questions.explanation: The person's understanding of their beliefs may differ from official teaching. Identify what they personally believed, based on their own words and writings.
questions.studyTip: Quote your person about their beliefs. What did THEY say?

questions.text: 'Beliefs' and 'faith in those beliefs' mean the same thing in exam questions.
questions.explanation: These are different concepts. Beliefs are ideas about religious matters. Faith means trust, confidence, and assured acceptance of those beliefs. The question may ask about both.
questions.studyTip: Beliefs = ideas. Faith = trust in those ideas. Answer both.

questions.text: Questions may require you to address both beliefs (ideas) and faith (trust, confidence) separately.
questions.explanation: When asked about faith in beliefs, explain how the experience affected not just what they believed, but their trust and commitment to those beliefs. These can change independently.
questions.studyTip: Did beliefs change? Did confidence in beliefs change? Both matter.

questions.text: Describing the significant life experience thoroughly shows how beliefs were affected.
questions.explanation: The focus must be on how beliefs were affected, not the experience itself. State the experience briefly, then demonstrate the connection: this happened, therefore their beliefs changed in this way.
questions.studyTip: Experience = brief setup. Effect on beliefs = main content.

questions.text: You must explicitly demonstrate how the experience changed, strengthened, or challenged beliefs.
questions.explanation: Show the mechanism: Did the experience confirm beliefs? Challenge them? Lead to new understanding? Be explicit about cause and effect between experience and belief change.
questions.studyTip: Use: 'This led to...' 'As a result...' 'Therefore their belief...'

questions.text: Any well-known religious figure works as a case study for significant life experiences.
questions.explanation: Some case studies don't work well because there's little to say about how beliefs changed. Choose a person whose significant life experience clearly and demonstrably affected their religious beliefs.
questions.studyTip: Good case study = clear evidence of belief change from the experience.

questions.text: Effective case studies show clear, documented changes in beliefs resulting from the experience.
questions.explanation: Research whether your person wrote or spoke about how their experience affected their beliefs. If you can't find evidence of belief change, consider a different case study.
questions.studyTip: Can you quote them about how their beliefs changed? If not, reconsider.

questions.text: Stimulus statements are optional context; you can answer without addressing them.
questions.explanation: Students generally handled stimulus statements poorly. When a question includes a stimulus statement, you must engage with it—analyse its relevance, agree or disagree with it, apply it to your example.
questions.studyTip: Stimulus statement = part of the question. Address it explicitly.

questions.text: When provided, stimulus statements must be explicitly addressed and analysed in your response.
questions.explanation: Don't just mention the statement—analyse its relevance to your challenge or case study. Is it accurate? Partially true? Does your example support or contradict it?
questions.studyTip: Quote the stimulus. Then: 'This is/isn't supported by my example because...'

questions.text: A well-prepared summary of key knowledge points makes a strong extended response.
questions.explanation: Many extended responses were abbreviated summaries of key knowledge rather than answers to the specific question. Select from your knowledge what addresses this question, not everything you know.
questions.studyTip: The question selects your content, not your preparation.

questions.text: Extended responses must select relevant content to address the specific question, not summarise everything studied.
questions.explanation: Read the question carefully. What is it specifically asking? Choose only the knowledge that answers that. A focused response beats a comprehensive dump.
questions.studyTip: Ask: What does THIS question need? Include only that.

questions.text: Command terms like 'analyse', 'evaluate', and 'describe' can be approached similarly.
questions.explanation: Each command term requires a specific type of response. 'Describe' needs what and how. 'Analyse' needs component identification and relationships. 'Evaluate' needs judgement with supporting evidence.
questions.studyTip: Learn command terms. They tell you HOW to answer.

questions.text: 'Analyse' requires identifying components and their relationships; 'evaluate' requires making a supported judgement.
questions.explanation: Know the VCAA command terms. 'Describe' ≠ 'analyse' ≠ 'evaluate'. Match your response type to the command word. This is a basic skill that distinguishes high-scoring responses.
questions.studyTip: Memorise: Describe = what. Analyse = how/why. Evaluate = judge.

questions.text: Making clear claims is the most important part; supporting detail can be brief.
questions.explanation: Many responses made claims but lacked supporting detail. Claims need evidence, explanation, and examples. An unsupported claim earns fewer marks than a well-evidenced one.
questions.studyTip: Claim → Evidence → Explanation. Every time.

questions.text: Every claim requires supporting detail—evidence, explanation, or examples—to earn full marks.
questions.explanation: Don't just assert; demonstrate. If you claim a challenge had certain consequences, show those consequences with specific evidence. Support is what turns assertions into arguments.
questions.studyTip: After each claim, ask: What's my evidence for this?

questions.text: Using Unit 3 Area of Study 1 category headings as beliefs shows structural knowledge.
questions.explanation: Some responses incorrectly used category headings (nature of God, nature of human person, etc.) as if they were beliefs. These are categories containing beliefs, not beliefs themselves.
questions.studyTip: Category headings organise beliefs. They are not beliefs.

questions.text: Belief category headings must be filled with specific theological content to count as beliefs.
questions.explanation: 'Nature of God' is a category. 'The belief that God is Trinity—Father, Son, and Holy Spirit—is one God in three persons' is a belief within that category. State the actual belief.
questions.studyTip: Fill the category with content. That content is the belief.

concepts.title: Sources of stances vs types of stances

questions.text: When asked about sources of stances, you should discuss the different types of stances religions take.
questions.explanation: Students confuse 'sources of stances' (what religions use to decide their stance) with 'types of stances' (for, against, accommodation). These are different questions requiring different answers.
questions.studyTip: Sources = what they consult. Types = the position they take. Different.

questions.text: Sources of stances are what religions consult (beliefs, texts, leaders); types of stances are the positions taken.
questions.explanation: Sources include beliefs, authority structures, official teachings, religious law, tradition, key individuals. Types are for, against, or accommodation. Know which the question asks.
questions.studyTip: Read carefully: Is it asking WHAT they consult or WHAT position they take?

concepts.title: Answering about religion vs religious beliefs

questions.text: Questions about 'religious beliefs' can be answered by discussing religion more broadly.
questions.explanation: Many students discussed 'religion' or 'significant life experiences' when the question specifically asked about 'religious beliefs.' These are different. Focus precisely on what's asked.
questions.studyTip: Religious beliefs ≠ religion ≠ religious practices. Be precise.

questions.text: When asked specifically about 'religious beliefs', you must focus on beliefs, not religion generally.
questions.explanation: If the question mentions 'religious beliefs', every part of your answer should discuss beliefs specifically—not practices, not community, not ethics (unless they connect directly to beliefs).
questions.studyTip: The question's exact words tell you exactly what to discuss.

questions.text: If you need two points, writing more on one point compensates for a weak second point.
questions.explanation: Questions requiring two points need two genuinely different ideas. Extended discussion of one point doesn't compensate for missing or reworded second point.
questions.studyTip: Two points means two ideas. Length doesn't replace the second idea.

questions.text: Each required point must be genuinely distinct; extended discussion of one point doesn't compensate for missing another.
questions.explanation: Plan before writing: identify two (or three) genuinely different ways to answer. Each point should add new information, not elaborate on previous points.
questions.studyTip: List your points before writing. Are they actually different?
